description: From Middle English siten, seten, from Old English seten, ġeseten, past participle of sittan (“to sit”). Cognate with Dutch gezeten, German gesessen.

adjectives.description: sitten (comparative more sitten, superlative most sitten)

examples: The tailȝeour was no thing weill sittin, He left the sadill.

entries.meaning: Settled; stationary; not easily stirred or moved.
examples: Their fire edge might help to kindle-up old sitten-up professours.

entries.meaning: (archaic, UK dialectal) past participle of sit; alternative form of sat
examples: For though we your brethren, who heretofore by our vocation have sitten in the chair of Moses, and be ghostly captains as Moses and Joshua unto you; [...]

description: From Middle English sitten, equivalent to sit +‎ -en.

examples: Such merimake holy saints doth queme,
But we here sytten as drownd in a dreme.
